awd_titl_txt: R/V Marcus G Langseth - Oceanographic Instrumentation 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
A proposal is made to fund instrumentation on the R/V Marcus Langseth, a 235’ Global seismic vessel with general oceanographic capabilities. The vessel is owned by Columbia University and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University under a cooperative agreement with NSF. The Langseth is unique in the Academic Fleet in that it provides a unique combination of capabilities for imaging the oceans, the seafloor and the solid earth beneath the sea. It is the only vessel in the world dedicated to academic research that is capable of conducting 3D seismic surveys as well as extended offset 2D surveys. The tuned, linear source array, consisting of up to 36 airguns, with a total capacity of 6,600 cu in is also unique asset of this vessel. All of the requested equipment in this proposal is for upgrading existing systems. Instrumentation requested in this proposal includes:

4x Sercel Seal Short Head Section	$75,200
2x Sercel Seal Short Head Elastic Section Adapter	$27,692
1x Umbilical Armored lead-in	$81,950
						$184,842
Broader Impacts								
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The R/V Marcus G. Langseth is a global class vessel in the US Academic Research Fleet that serves as National Seismic Imaging Facility.  This research vessel has significant 2D and 3D seismic imaging capability that allows it too provide detailed information deep below ocean seafloor to scientists that study the materials and geologic processes that cannot be directly observed.  To collect this data, the Langseth must tow both a seismic source and long hydrophone (listening devices) streamers that collect the acoustic reflections that bounce off sediment/rock layers in the subseafloor to create an image using specialized software.  The towed streamers are made up of a variety of different sections at the ship that allow up to 12-15km (7.4 to 9.3miles) long streamers to be towed safely from the vessel and for data from the hydrophones to flow  to the ship's computers for processing.  

The 2022 Oceanographic Instrumentation award provided funding which allowed us to obtain additional section pieces of equipment for our Multi-Channel Seismic (MCS) hydrophone streamer system. These pieces included four Short Head Sections, two Head Elastic Section Adapters and one Armored Lead-In Core. These sections are part of what is referred to as the front end ( the ship end) of the towed components of the Langseth MCS system.  This equipment allowed for the replacement of existing equipment that had reached end-of-life and for additional spares that can be used as necessary as backup components in case of a failure or damage at sea so that we can avoid vessel downtime during projects. 

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2023
Modified by: Sean M Higgins

    LDEO/Sandbox Studios, San Francisco

    R/V Marcus G Langseth

The R/V Marcus G. Langseth is a global class vessel in the US Academic Research Fleet that serves as National Seismic Imaging Facility.  This research vessel has significant 2D and 3D seismic imaging capability that allows it too provide detailed information deep below ocean seafloor to scientists that study the materials and geologic processes that cannot be directly observed.  To collect this data, the Langseth must tow both a seismic source and long hydrophone (listening devices) streamers that collect the acoustic reflections that bounce off sediment/rock layers in the subseafloor to create an image using specialized software.  The towed streamers are made up of a variety of different sections at the ship that allow up to 12-15km (7.4 to 9.3miles) long streamers to be towed safely from the vessel and for data from the hydrophones to flow  to the ship's computers for processing.  

The 2022 Oceanographic Instrumentation award provided funding which allowed us to obtain additional section pieces of equipment for our Multi-Channel Seismic (MCS) hydrophone streamer system. These pieces included four Short Head Sections, two Head Elastic Section Adapters and one Armored Lead-In Core. These sections are part of what is referred to as the front end ( the ship end) of the towed components of the Langseth MCS system.  This equipment allowed for the replacement of existing equipment that had reached end-of-life and for additional spares that can be used as necessary as backup components in case of a failure or damage at sea so that we can avoid vessel downtime during projects.
